children.name: fantasy b2
children.definition: fantasy an exciting or enjoyable experience that you imagine happening to you, but which will probably never happen: tưởng tượng
examples: sexual fantasies
young children sometimes can’t distinguish between fantasy and reality.
everyone’s fantasy is that one day they will win the national lottery.
have a fantasy
i used tohave fantasies aboutliving in paris with an artist.
live in a fantasy worldto always be having fantasies sống trong thế giới tưởng tượng
my son seems to live in a fantasy world sometimes.
helived inafantasy worldof his own, even as a small boy.

children.name: imaginary c1
children.definition: imaginary not real, but existing only as a picture or idea in your mind:tưởng tượng
examples: when linda was a child she had an imaginary friend called booboo.
he pointed an imaginary gun at me and pretended to shoot.
frankie was the kind of guy who lived in an imaginary world all of his own.
as she listened, she played an imaginary piano on her knees.
we must protect older people from harm, whether it is real or imaginary.

children.name: hallucination x
children.definition: hallucination sth you see that does not really exist, especially sth that you see because you are ill or have taken drugs: ảo tưởng, ảo giác
examples: i knew that what i had seen was a hallucination, but it was so real and frightening.have hallucinations
jamie lost two and a half stone in the next fortnight, couldn’t eat and had hallucinations.

children.name: vision b2
children.definition: vision an image, especially a religious image, that you can see but which other people cannot: cảnh tượng
examples: have a vision
bernadette had a vision in which the virgin mary appeared before her.
shehadavisionin which jesus appeared before her.
johnny was late home and, as usual, ihadvisionsofhim lying dead in some alley
we see in his novels his sinister, almost apocalyptic, visionofthe future.
in a vision
he became a monk after seeing saint apollinaris in a vision.

children.name: daydream x
children.definition: daydream a series of pleasant thoughts that go through your mind when you are awake, so that you do not notice what is happening around you: mơ mộng
examples: neil was in a daydream, and didn’t hear the teacher call his name.
he never paid attention in class and seemed to be in a permanent daydream.
i was just enjoying a daydream about winning the nobel prize for literature.

children.name: picture b2
children.definition: picturenounimagehình, hình ảnh
examples: [ c ] something you produce in your mind, by using your imagination or memory
_i have a veryvividpicture of the first time i met erik.

children.name: to have a picture or idea of st in your mind
picture c1
children.definition: picture to have a clear picture of sb/sth in your mind, especially because you are trying to imagine what it is like to do sth or what sb looks like: hình dung, mường tượng
examples: tom, picturing the scene, smiled.
can you picture it? lying in the sun, sipping cocktails -- it would be paradise!
picture sb/sth as sth
rob had pictured her as serious, but she wasn’t like that.
picture sb doing sth
i can’t picture him skiing. he’s so clumsy!
i had never met graham but i pictured him as a pale, thin young man wearing glasses.
picture what/how
picture what it would be like after a nuclear attack.
miguel could still picture the children laughing and joking, and chasing each other around the garden.

children.name: imagine b1
children.definition: imagine to think about sth and form a picture or idea in your mind about it:tưởng tượng
examples: try to imagine a room as big as a football field.
imagine (that)
imagine that you have just won a million pounds.
imagine life without hot water.
imagine what/how/why etc
can you imagine what it’s like when it’s really hot out here in delhi?
(just) imagine doing sth
imagine doing a horrible job like that!
just imagine going all that way for nothing!
imagine sb doing sth
she could imagine dark-robed figures moving silently along the stone corridors.
imagine sb/sth as something
he didn’t quite dare to imagine himself as a real artist.
imagine sb in/with/without etc something
somehow, i can’t imagine him without a beard.
it’s difficult/easy/possible/impossible etc to imagine something
after such a dry summer, it’s difficult to imagine what rain looks like.
be easy to imagineit’s easy to imagine how the change in the law caused a lot of confusion.
be hard/difficult to imagineit’s hard to imagine the suffering she must have gone through.
can easily imaginei can easily imagine how frightening the accident must have been.
can well imagine(= can easily imagine )i can well imagine how delighted you were with the news.
can hardly/scarcely imagine(= find it difficult to imagine )he could scarcely imagine what living in such poor conditions must have been like.
can’t/couldn’t imaginehe couldn’t imagine life without his wife.
what somebody had imagined(= what someone thought something would be like, before they saw it or experienced it )the office was not what he had imagined.
be bigger/smaller/worse etc than you had imaginedthe job interview proved to be much worse than i had imagined it would be.
let us imagine …(= used to encourage someone else to think about a possibility )let us imagine that you are an employer who wants to recruit some new staff.
sb is imagining things(= someone has a false or wrong idea about something )she’s imagining things if she thinks she has a chance of winning the prize.
naively imagine(= to imagine something without realizing how complicated the situation is )she had naively imagined that marriage would solve all her problems.
fondly imagine(= to believe something that is untrue )he had fondly imagined that she was in love with him.

children.name: can see u
children.partOfSpeech: [vp not in progressive or in passive]
children.definition: can see to have a clear picture of sth you are thinking about in your mind, especially sthpleasantorfunny, or something you think islikelytohappen:có thể thấy
examples: ▪ i’m going to corfu next week. i can see it all now -- sun, sand and sea!
can see sb doing sth
▪ jimmy’s gone skiing for the first time. i can just see him coming home with a broken leg.

children.name: visualize x
children.definition: visualize/visualiseuk  to form a very clear picture of sb/sth in your mind, especially in order to help you prepare to do something or help you to remember something clearly:hình dung
examples: i tried to visualize the house while he was describing it.
visualize somebody doing something
somehow i can’t visualize myself staying with this company for much longer.
visualize how/what etc
it’s hard to visualize how these tiles will look in our bathroom.
he closed his eyes, trying to visualize where he had put his watch.

children.name: form a picture b2
children.definition: form a picture to form an idea of sth in your mind, using the information you have about it: hình dung
examples: the hubble space telescope allows astronomers to form a more accurate picture of our solar system.

children.name: conceive c2
children.definition: conceive formal to imagine a situation, especially one that is difficult to imagine - use this especially in questions and negative statements: tưởng tượng, hình dung
examples: it is difficult to conceive of a society in which nobody has to work.
(cannot) conceive of (doing) sth
many people can’t conceive of a dinner without meat or fish.
i don’t know about you, but i cannot conceive of a home without electricity or water.
for many people, music is so important that they cannot conceive of life without it.
conceive that
he could not conceive that anything really serious could be worrying his friend.
conceive what/why/how etc
i can hardly conceive what it must be like here in winter.
conceive of sb/sth as sth
language may be conceived of as a process which arises from social interaction.

children.name: imagination b1
children.definition: imagination the ability to form pictures or ideas in your mind : sức tưởng tượng
examples: a storyteller with an incredible imagination
it does not take much imagination to understand their grief.
with a little imagination, you can find great inexpensive gifts.
use your imagination
i don’t have a photograph with me so you’ll have to use your imagination.
a good imaginationshe's a lively child, with a good imagination.
great imaginationhis paintings show great imagination.

a vivid/fertile imagination(= an ability to think of a lot of ideas and things that could happen )she had a fertile imagination and a great sense of humour.|with your vivid imagination, you should write a book.
an overactive/fevered imagination(= a mind that imagines strange things that are not real )these stories are the product of an overactive imagination.
the public imaginationthe story captured the public imagination.
creative imaginationi don't have the creative imagination to be a writer.
have (an) imaginationher poems show that she has a lot of imagination.
use your imaginationmusicians need to use their imagination as well as their technical skills.
show/display imaginationhis latest paintings display a vivid imagination.
lack imaginationa lot of today's pop music seems to lack imagination.
fire/stimulate somebody's imagination(= make someone use their imagination )the aim of the exhibition is to stimulate people's imagination.
be full of imaginationher stories are full of imagination.
a lack of imaginationtheir policies show a lack of imagination.

let your imagination run wild(alsolet your imagination run riotbritish english) (= allow yourself to imagine many strange or wonderful things )he uses painting as a way of letting his imagination run riot.

children.name: to wrongly think that sth is happening
be seeing things x
children.definition: be seeing things especiallyspokensay this when you or sb else has imagined something that cannot be real:tưởng tượng, ảo giác
examples: i/you/he etc must be seeing things
‘did that man just wave at me?’ ‘of course not, you must be seeing things.’

children.name: imagine b1
children.definition: imagine to have a false or wrong idea about sth :tưởng rằng
examples: perhaps she’d never really been there at all – perhaps she’d just imagined it.
imagined dangers
imagine (that)
she had imagined that the doctor would be male.
i was surprised when i saw the farm. i had imagined it would be much bigger.
when i was a child i would lie awake imagining that there were monsters in the dark corners of my room.
mary was always imagining that people were talking about her behind her back.
imagine sb/sth to be sth
i/you/he etc must be imagining thingsanh chỉ tưởng vậy thôi
‘i’m sure i saw brian in the park today.’ ‘no, you must be imagining things. brian hasn’t lived here for nearly fifteen years.’
there’s nobody here. you’re justimagining things.

children.name: be in the mind x
children.definition: be in the mind/be in your mind if something is in the mind or in your mind, you are imagining it and it does not really exist: chỉ là do tưởng tượng thôi
examples: i don’t think martin is really ill -- it’s all in the mind.
his doctor tried to convince him that he wasn't really ill and that it was all in the mind.
no-one is trying to kill you. it’s all in your mind.

children.name: hallucinate x
children.definition: hallucinateto imagine that you are seeing things that are not really there, especially because you are ill or have taken drugs : bịảo giác
examples: after two days without food and water, voss began to hallucinate.
the drug that can cause some people to hallucinate.
when i saw the walls moving, i thought i must be hallucinating.

children.name: figment of your imagination
children.definition: sth that does not really exist and that you were just imagining: sự tưởng tượng
examples: sceptics will tell you that there is no such thing as reincarnation and that living a previous life is a figment of the subject’s imagination.

children.name: to imagine sth you want to do or happen
dream b1
children.definition: dreamto imagine sthpleasantthat you would like to do or to happen, especially if it is possible that it might happen:
examples: dream of/about (doing) sth
she dreamed of becoming a chef.
he’s got the sort of money that you and i canonly dream about.
dream (that)
she dreamed that one day she would be famous.

children.name: reverie x
children.definition: reverieformal literarya state of imagining or thinking about pleasant things, that is like dreaming: mơ màng
examples: the doorbell rang, shaking me from my reverie.
sometimes he would drift off into reverie, and gaze out of the window for hours.
she was startled out of her reverie by a loud crash.
in reverie
he was lostinreverie until he suddenly heard someone behind him.

children.name: daydream c1
children.definition: daydream to imagine pleasant things, so that you forget where you are and what you should be doing :
examples: mark began to daydream, and didn’t even hear the teacher’s question.
stop daydreaming and get on with your work!
mark had begun to daydream, and didn’t even hear the teacher’s question.
daydream about/of
carol sat at her desk, daydreaming about meeting mel gibson.
when charles tapped me on the shoulder i was daydreaming of golden beaches and palm trees.
what are you daydreaming about? there’s work to be done.
daydreamer[ c ]

children.name: fantasize x
children.definition: fantasize/fantasiseuk  to think about something that you would like to do or that you would like to happen, especially when it is very unlikely that you will do it or that it will happen: mơ mộng viển vông, hão huyền
examples: fantasize about
i often fantasize about living in a big house with tennis courts and a swimming pool.
many men fantasize about sleeping with someone who is not their partner.
sometimes she fantasized about buying a boat and sailing around the world.
fantasize that
i used to fantasize that my real parents were famous movie stars.

children.name: think of/about sb/sth b1
children.definition: think of/aboutsb/sthphrasal verb
examples: to remember or imagine someone or something
_i thought of you immediately when they said they wanted someone who could speak english.
_he was thinking about the time he spent in the army.

children.name: vision c1
children.definition: visionnounview of the futuretầm nhìn( về tương lai )
examples: [ u ] the ability to imagine how a country, society, industry, etc. could develop in the future and to plan in a suitable way
_he didn't have the mental agility or vision required for a senior politician.
_a person of great artistic vision

children.name: in your mind's eye c2
children.definition: inyourmind's eye
examples: in your imagination or memory
_in my mind's eye, she remains a little girl of six although she's actually a grown woman.

children.name: imagination b1
children.definition: imaginationnoun sức tưởng tượng
examples: [ u ] the ability to think of new ideas
_it's a job that needs someone with a bit of imagination.

children.name: image c2
children.definition: imagenounmental picture hình, hình ảnh
examples: [ c ] a picture in your mind or an idea of how someone or something is
_i have an image in my mind of how i want the garden to be.
_he doesn'tfit(= he is different to) my image of how an actor should look.
